text: ooh hi hi everyone
Anthony Fantana here the Internet's
busiest music nerd and it's time for a
review of the new Morrissey Record world
peace is none of your business
Morrissey singer-songwriter infamous
frontman of the Smiths and solo artist I
think it's pretty safe to say that
without Morrissey and without the Smiths
alternative rock n' and jangle pop
wouldn't quite be the same with records
like the queen is dead Mia's murder
Strangeways Viva Hate if you haven't
heard any of these records I would say
take this review as an opportunity or an
invitation to go take a moment and check
those records out because to me this new
record from Morrissey is is not really
up to snuff but quality wise in the line
enough with his most recent releases to
the point where anybody who's been
following Morrissey up until this point
will not be just devastatingly
disappointed by what happens on this
record personally I don't really have
that intimate of a relationship with
Morrissey's solo discography outside of
some of this bigger earlier releases and
because of records like world peace is
none of your business it's probably
going to stay that way the instrumentals
on this record track for track four
track are way too stiff too flabby too
winded to do anything that's
legitimately exciting or display any
real kind of finesse especially as some
of the guitars and drums are clumsily
reenacting music of a Spanish origin but
the end result just feels watered-down
to the highest degree the whole record
thinks it's way more moving and
convincing than it actually is and again
those are just the instruments vocally I
think this album lacks as well these
days at this stage in his career
listening to more so he's like listening
to Frank Sinatra with no charm no
swagger
I think over time Morrissey has just
slowly become a crooner with no charisma
there are
few songs on here namely staircase at
the University where Morrissey really
shows off his pop sensibilities and
these songs go over well not only do we
get good chord progressions good
melodies but the instrumentation feels a
little more upbeat and peppy too but
outside of these more accessible songs
this record is just kind of an
opportunity for Morrissey to throw
himself on top of a philosophical
pedestal and look down his nose at the
unwashed masses who he has supremely
exceeded in terms of mental capabilities
seems all the filthy dirty people down
there just can't figure out why there's
all this war and poverty and injustice
around but thank God we have Morrissey
here to tell us world peace is none of
your business I'm completely 100%
wholeheartedly all four-alarm when it
comes to a justified and positive cause
Morrissey for the most part has always
been pretty upfront with his ideals in
his songs what he thinks about the world
at large and ideologically there are
some things I agree with him on namely
animal rights and religion I'm sure but
in my opinion I think a lot of the time
Morrissey presents his ideas in a way
that is kind of obnoxious and insulting
to listeners even listeners who may
agree with what he's saying even as
somebody who doesn't enjoy bullfighting
I had a hard time enjoying the song
bullfighter dies namely because even if
you agree with the ideology of a track
if it is created in bitterness it tastes
bitter to everyone there are tracks on
here like not a man where it seems like
Morrissey isn't even really concerned
with whatever melody he's singing he
just wants to get these lyrics out that
seem to just be tearing him up inside he
just has these proclamations that he
that he is dying to make I would never
destroy this planet on the title track
he sort of repeats this mantra over and
over and over that voting just supports
the process of all this injustice all
this oppression
and you know I completely believe in
your right to believe that and defend
your argument if you actually have some
interesting and thought-provoking points
but to just kind of put something so
blatantly arguable out there just kind
of seems to me like lazy lyric-writing I
don't know I mean there are countries
all across the world first world
countries where especially in America
where the are blow in these days some of
them in some states especially local
elections they are historically low and
I can't really say that we're more free
because of it when it comes to
government oppression and government
corruption there's a lot more to its
existence than people voting then
there's the song earth is the loneliest
planet where Morrissey essentially comes
off completely disillusioned with the
human race the future of the human race
the future of the world and I completely
sympathize I mean I think anybody who
Ponder's or is an introspective person
has these kinds of thoughts however
there's not really anything in this song
in this record as a whole that leads me
to believe that Morrissey comes to this
conclusion from a place of enlightenment
to me Morrissey presents a lot of his
political philosophy across this tract
with just unbridled pretension with not
even a note of humor or a poignant idea
or anything even close to a solution
maybe if you're a hardcore fan you're
living and dying by Morrissey you have a
Morrissey face tattoo I can see you
enjoying what this record has to offer
because what you care about is Morrissey
and for sure he lays a lot of his ideas
and a lot of his emotions on the line
with this record he puts it out there
it's straightforward it's for all to see
or rather hear but coming from the
standpoint of someone who doesn't have
that kind of personal or emotional
connection to Morrissey just because
he's Morrissey I find that the songs on
here that do have strong pop
sensibilities those are good but outside
of that I'm getting a lot of
instrumental fodder
which is completely underwhelming and
thrown on top of it
are these really stale bitter political
and philosophical musings that to me are
kind of self-serving as somebody who
might agree with some of morsi's points
I don't really get anything out of
hearing him state them and what he
brings to the table on this record as
far as his lyrics don't really strike me
as something that would turn around
somebody who might disagree with him I'm
feeling a strong four to a light five on
this LP transition if you've given this
record to listen what did you think of
it did you love it did you hate it why
what do you think I should review next
and that's it Anthony Fantana more sieve
on Morrissey man forever
